facts.text: High Court of Judicature, Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad passed an order dated 9th March, 2007

anchor.surface_text: an order dated 9th March, 2007 passed by the High Court of Judicature, Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad whereby the High Court has set aside the order passed by the State Admini

facts.text: High Court set aside the order passed by the State Administrative Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997 to the extent it holds the judgment in V. Jagannadha Rao case prospective

anchor.surface_text: an order dated 9th March, 2007 passed by the High Court of Judicature, Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad whereby the High Court has set aside the order passed by the State Administrate Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997 to the extent the same holds the judgment of this Court in V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.  2001  10 SCC 401, to be prospective in its application.

facts.text: High Court passed an order dated 3rd November, 2010 dismissing review petition filed by the appellants

anchor.surface_text: . An order dated 3rd November, 2010 passed by the High Court dismissing a review petition filed by the appellants against the said order has also been assailed.

facts.text: State Administrative Tribunal passed order in OA No.6334 of 1997

anchor.surface_text: the State Administrate Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997 to the extent the same holds the judgment of this Court in V. Jagannadha Rao

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment in V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors. reported as 2001 10 SCC 401

anchor.surface_text: V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.  2001  10 SCC 401, to be prospective in its application.

facts.text: Presidential Order dated 18th October, 1975 issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: the Presidential Order dated 18th October, 1975 issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution was aimed at providing equitable opportunities and facilities to the people belonging to different parts of the State in the matter of public employment, education etc.

facts.text: Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 permitted appointment by transfer to higher category on basis of seniority-cum-efficiency

anchor.surface_text: a three-Judge Bench was examining whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5 2  of the Presidential Order issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution of India, 1950.

facts.text: GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 made UDCs in Labour Department and Factories and Boilers Department eligible for recruitment by transfer to posts of Assistant Inspector of Labour and Assistant Inspector of Factories

anchor.surface_text: The question had arisen on account of a challenge mounted by the Ministerial employees of the Labour Department against GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 whereunder UDCs in the Labour Department and those working in Factories and Boilers Department were made eligible for recruitment by transfer to the posts of Assistant Inspectors of Labour and Assistant Inspectors of Factories.

facts.text: Full Bench of Tribunal declared impugned Rules violative of paras 3 and 5 of Presidential Order

anchor.surface_text: A full Bench of Tribunal before whom the challenge came up for consideration declared that the impugned Rules to the extent they enabled the Ministerial employees of the Factories and Boilers Department or any other department to be considered for appointment to the posts in the Labour Department were violative of paras 3 and 5 of the Presidential Order and hence void.

facts.text: Supreme Court in V. Jagannadha Rao case dismissed appeals of aggrieved employees

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the Tribunal was questioned before this Court by the aggrieved employees. Dismissing the appeals, this Court held that according to the scheme of the Presidential Order, local cadre was the unit under para 5 1  thereof for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion and transfers.

facts.text: G.O.M. No.14, Labour Employment Training Ser. IV Department, dated 26th November, 1994 as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996

anchor.surface_text: The present batch of cases relates to G.O.M. No.14, Labour Employment Training  Ser. IV  Department, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996.

facts.text: G.O.Ms provide that Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in Head Offices shall be eligible for appointment by transfer to post of Assistant Labour Officer

anchor.surface_text: These two G.O.Ms. provide that while Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Subordinate Offices of the Labour Department constitute the feeding channel under Rule 3 of Andhra Pradesh Labour Subordinate Service Rules, Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Head Offices shall also be eligible for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

facts.text: Employees approached Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal aggrieved by G.O.Ms

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the G.O.Ms. some of the employees approached the Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal for redressal.

facts.text: Tribunal partly allowed petitions by order dated 7th March, 2003 striking down G.O.M. No.14 dated 26th November, 1994 as amended prospectively

anchor.surface_text: These petitions were partly allowed by the Tribunal in terms of its order dated 7th March, 2003 and G.O.M. No.14, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996 struck down as unconstitutional to the extent the same provided a channel for Senior Assistant and Senior Stenographer in Andhra Pradesh Ministerial Service working in the Head Offices of Labour Department and those in Factories and Boiler Departments besides those in the Subordinate Offices in the said Departments for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

facts.text: Tribunal directed striking down prospective and no disturbance of actions till 7th November, 2001 and no reversion of promoted employees

anchor.surface_text: Having said that the Tribunal directed that the striking down of the impugned O.Ms. would only be prospective and that any action taken in compliance with the said Rules till 7th November, 2001 shall not be disturbed nor any employee promoted on the basis of the legal position that prevailed earlier to the decision of this Court in V. Jagannadha Raos case  supra  reverted.

facts.text: Writ Petition No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 filed challenging Tribunal judgment to extent saving promotions

anchor.surface_text: The aggrieved employees, who had approached the Tribunal having succeeded but only in part, filed Writ Petitions No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 whereby they challenged the judgment of the Tribunal to the extent it saved the promotions already made on the basis of the impugned G.O.Ms.

facts.text: Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 filed against Tribunal judgment holding G.O.Ms violative

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 was also filed against the very same judgment by some of the employees who felt aggrieved by the view taken by the Tribunal that the impugned G.O.Ms. were in violation of the Presidential Order hence unconstitutional.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court allowed Writ Petitions No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 and dismissed No.16890 of 2006

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh has, in terms of the judgment and order under challenge before us, allowed Writ Petitions No.6123 and 6068 of 2004 but dismissed Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 relying upon certain decisions rendered by this Court.

facts.text: Appellants filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010 against High Court judgment

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in these appeals are employees who were not arrayed as parties to the writ petition filed before the High Court. Feeling aggrieved of the judgment and order passed by the High Court they filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010

facts.text: High Court dismissed review petitions on 3rd November, 2010

anchor.surface_text: The review petitions were, accordingly, dismissed and the prayer for grant of leave to appeal to this Court rejected.

facts.text: Petitions filed before State Administrative Tribunal in the year 1997

anchor.surface_text: The petitions in the present case were filed before the State Administrative Tribunal in the year 1997.

facts.text: Tribunal struck down rules by order dated 27th March, 2003 but saved promotions already made

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal had on the authority of the judgment aforementioned struck down the rules providing for ex-cadre zone promotions by its order dated 27th March, 2003, but saved the promotions already made.

facts.text: Promotions made before 7th November, 2001 continued for nearly ten years

anchor.surface_text: Promotions made before the pronouncement of the order in Jagannadha Raos case  supra  i.e. before 7th November, 2001 have, thus, continued for nearly ten years till the review petition filed by the petitioners was dismissed

facts.text: Commissioner of Labour filed additional affidavit stating no need to create supernumerary posts

anchor.surface_text: An additional affidavit filed by the Commissioner of Labour, Government of Andhra Pradesh, however, does not appear to be supportive of what could be a solution to the stalemate arising out of the impugned judgment.

facts.text: Petitioners while working as Senior Assistants opted to go as Assistant Labour Officers outside regular line

anchor.surface_text: The affidavit states that the petitioners while working as Senior Assistants and senior stenographers had opted to go as Assistant Labour Officers outside the regular line on executive posts where the incumbents enforce the labour laws.

arguments.claim: Inclusion of Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers from Head Offices of Labour Department and Factories and Boiler Departments in the feeding channel for appointment by transfer to Assistant Labour Officer (zonal post) violates paras 3(3) and 5(1) of Presidential Order

anchor.surface_text: Their grievance primarily was that since the post of Assistant Labour Officer is a zonal post, employees working in the respective zones alone were entitled to be included in the feeding channel. Inclusion of other categories from outside the zone in the feeding channel for purposes of promotion or appointment by transfer was offensive to paras 3 3  and 5 1  of the Andhra Pradesh Public Employment  Organisation of Local Cards and Regulation of Direct Recruitment  Order, 1975 referred to hereinabove as the Presidential Order against the employees.

arguments.claim: High Court judgment invalid as passed without impleading necessary parties (promoted employees like appellants)

anchor.surface_text: Feeling aggrieved of the judgment and order passed by the High Court they filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010, inter alia, contending that the judgment under review had been passed without impleading employees like the appellants as parties to the case even though they were bound to be adversely affected by any modification that the High Court may have made. It was contended that the review petitioners-appellants before us in these appeals were necessary parties not only to the O.As filed before the State Administrative Tribunal but even to the writ petitions filed before the High Court and that in the absence of necessary parties to the proceedings the petitions challenging the Rules were liable to be dismissed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ee promoted on the basis of the legal position that prevailed earlier to the decision of this Court in V. Jagannadha Raos case  supra  reverted. The a

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court: aggrieved should file separate writ; SC uses as factor for prospective overruling

arguments.claim: Predominant opinion limits prospective overruling to Supreme Court only; neither Tribunal nor High Court can invoke

anchor.surface_text: It was contended by the counsel appearing for the respondents that the predominant legal opinion emerging from the pronouncements of this Court limited the application of the doctrine of prospective overruling only by the Supreme Court. Neither the Tribunal nor the High Court could, according to the learned counsel, have invoked the doctrine assuming that there was any justification for such invocation in the facts and circumstances of the case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of supernumerary posts in the Directorate for the petitioners who were working as Assistant Labour Officers, Assistant Commissioners of Labour and Dep

arguments.claim: Supreme Court can invoke prospective overruling even if High Court could not, given long-held positions, reversion harsh, law in flux

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Jayant Bhushan, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of the respondent, on the other hand, argued and, in our opinion, rightly so that it was unnecessary for this Court to go into the question whether the doctrine of prospective overruling was available even to the High Court. He urged that there could be no manner of doubt that even if the High Court was not competent to invoke the doctrine, nothing prevented this Court from doing so having regard to the fact that those promoted under the impugned rules had held their respective positions for a considerable length of time making reversion to their parent zone cadre not only administratively difficult but unreasonably harsh and unfair.

arguments.claim: GOMs framed under Art 309 violative of Presidential Order para 5(2); transfer does not include promotion

anchor.surface_text: a three-Judge Bench was examining whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5 2  of the Presidential Order issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution of India, 1950.

arguments.claim: Presidential Order prevails over Art 309 rules per Art 371D(10)

anchor.surface_text: in terms of Article 371-D(10) of the Constitution any order made by the President shall have effect notwithstanding anything in any other provision of the Constitution or in any law for the time being in force.

holdings.text: Special Rules framed under proviso to Article 309 permitting appointment by transfer to higher category on basis of seniority-cum-efficiency are violative of para 5(2) of Presidential Order under Article 371-D.

anchor.surface_text: a three-Judge Bench was examining whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5(2) of the Presi

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent from V. Jagannadha Rao case applied; para 5(2) authorizes transfer in specified circumstances but term transfer cannot be enlarged to include promotion; Presidential Order prevails over Art 309 rules per Art 371-D(10).

holdings.text: Impugned G.O.Ms enabling ministerial employees from Factories and Boilers or other departments/Head Offices for appointment by transfer to posts in Labour Department violate paras 3 and 5 of Presidential Order.

anchor.surface_text: the impugned Rules to the extent they enabled the Ministerial employees of the Factories and Boilers Department or any other department to be considered for appointment to the posts in the Labour Department were violative of paras 3 and 5 of the Presidential Order and hence void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Local cadre under para 5(1) is unit for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion, transfers; Tribunal correctly struck down following V. Jagannadha Rao.

holdings.text: G.O.M. No.14 dated 26.11.1994 as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9.5.1996 violative of Presidential Order paras 3(3) and 5(1) to extent providing channel for Senior Assistants/Stenographers from Head Offices/Factories & Boilers Depts. for appointment by transfer to Assistant Labour Officer.

anchor.surface_text: These two G.O.Ms. provide that while Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Subordinate Offices of the Labour Department constitute the feeding channel under Rule 3 of Andhra Pradesh Labour Subordinate Service Rules, Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Head Offices shall also be eligible for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post is zonal; only employees in respective zones entitled to feeding channel; offensive to paras 3(3), 5(1); Tribunal struck down on authority of V. Jagannadha Rao.

holdings.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling invocable only by Supreme Court, not by High Courts under Article 226 or Tribunals.

anchor.surface_text: the doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by the Apex Court and not by other Court including High Courts exercising powers under Article 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Predominant legal opinion from Supreme Court pronouncements limits doctrine to Supreme Court; High Court correctly set aside Tribunal's prospective application.

holdings.text: Supreme Court invokes doctrine of prospective overruling under Article 142; striking down of G.O.Ms prospective, promotions/actions under impugned rules till 7th November 2001 not to be disturbed, no reversion.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Law in flux till V. Jagannadha Rao (7.11.2001); promotions continued nearly 10 years; reversion unjust/harsh/cascading effect; appointees not impleaded; Art 142 enables moulding relief for complete justice; differs from VJR on facts/rules.

holdings.text: Article 371-D(10) gives overriding effect to Presidential Order notwithstanding Art 309 rules or other laws.

anchor.surface_text: in terms of Article 371-D(10) of the Constitution any order made by the President shall have effect notwithstanding anything in any other provision of the Constitution or in any law for the time being in force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: If Presidential Order prohibits cross-cadre consideration, Art 309 rules liable to be struck down.

holdings.text: Para 5(2) of Presidential Order authorizes State provisions for transfer in specified circumstances but does not encompass promotion.

anchor.surface_text: local cadre was the unit under para 5(1) thereof for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion and transfers. This Court further held that while para 5(2) authorised the State Government to make provisions for transfer in certain specified circumstances, yet the term transfer could not be enlarged in its amplitude so as to include promotional aspects.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between transfer and promotion in para 5(1); read statute as whole; intention from language used.

precedents.cited_proposition: Special Rules under Article 309 permitting appointment by transfer to higher category on seniority-cum-efficiency violative of para 5(2) of Presidential Order under Article 371-D; transfer does not include promotion; Presidential Order prevails over such rules
precedents.cited_holding: the Rules framed by the State Government under proviso to Article 309 whereby UDCs of the Labour Department, and Factories and Boilers Department were made eligible for recruitment by transfer to the posts of Assistant Inspector of Labour Assistant Inspector of Factories were violative of the Presidential Order
